markdownRemark.html:
I was hired as the first engineer in Vroom’s new NYC HQ to rewrite Vroom.com on a modern tech stack.

Vroom.com is an ecommerce website for buying and selling used cars online, and Vroom has over $1b in revenue. I was honored to be given the task to rebuild their website from the ground up - any web engineer’s dream.

The Problem - Old Website

The existing website was powered by .NET and Azure on the backend, and had a bit of React on the frontend, but without any framework.

There were a host of problems on the old website:

  • Extremely slow. Any page on the site would take anywhere from 500ms-3s to load, and in the ecommerce world this literally translates to lost revenue.

  • Development time was slow.

Fixing new bugs and developing new features was time consuming.

  • Expensive

Server costs were relatively high.

My Proposal - New Website

I decided to build a Universal Javascript Single-Page App with Node.js, React, and Redux.

I remember the CEO approaching me to congratulate me on the website, saying it was blazing fast.

Code reviews

Management

We adopted agile/scrum for the sake of scoping out the work and giving a sense of structure. I did weekly 1-on-1 meetings with each member of my team to ensure no one was blocked and any concerns would be voiced.

I’m a strong believer in empowering individuals, and am very much against micromanagement as I believe it is unproductive and reduces morale. If somebody is delivering or not delivering, it’s fairly obvious to tell.

If a team member isn’t pulling his or her weight, I’ll tell them - and it’s never a surprise. If they don’t turn things around after that, when that doesn’t leave many options.

Feedback

The

Conclusion

I’m so grateful to have been given this opportunity. Specifically, I have to thank John Rodkey for believing in me. And of course I have to thank the team who brought this to life, and continue to carry it on after I’ve left (you know who you are).

The new site is blazing fast and light years ahead of the old one. Developing on the site is so easy it’s “boring” (in a good way :P). To be honest, I’d never seen an ecommerce site as a single-page app, but I’m convinced the entire web will eventually move to single-page apps as the technology gets more accessible. You just can’t beat the page speed performance of not having to refresh.
